Name: Early implementation
Description: The tool is implemented early in the conflict or rapidly after the appearance of early warning signs or occurrence of mass atrocities.
Inverse.factor.description: The tool is implemented late in the conflict or slowly after the appearance of early warning signs or occurrence of mass atrocities.
Description.Final_research: The tool is implemented early in the conflict or rapidly after the appearance of early warning signs or occurrence of mass atrocities.

Short.description: The official barring of legal proceedings against certain individuals or groups
Description_tool: An official amnesty is “an official legislative or executive act whereby criminal investigation or prosecution of an individual, a group or class of persons and/or certain offences is prospectively or retroactively barred, and any penalties cancelled” (ICRC 2017, p. 1).
Theory.of.change: If official amnesties increase the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, including by encouraging abusive leaders to give up power, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Name: Committed implementer
Description: The tool implementer has a high level of commitment, resolve, or credibility, or has committed a great deal of resources toward use of the tool.
Inverse.factor.description: The tool implementer has a low level of commitment, resolve, or credibility, or has committed few resources toward use of the tool.
Description.Final_research: The tool implementer has a high level of commitment, resolve, or credibility, or has committed a great deal of resources toward use of the tool.

Short.description: Aid that promotes economic growth, welfare, and humanitarian relief
Description_tool: Development assistance is “government aid that promotes and specifically targets the economic development and welfare of developing countries” (OECD). Development assistance is typically organized into sectors, including democracy, rights, and governance; economic growth; health; education; and humanitarian assistance (USAID). Our research review includes studies of the linkage between development assistance of any or all sectors with mass atrocities or closely related outcomes. As such, it is not a detailed review of alternative program-level interventions. Research reviews of programming options in conflict prevention and peacebuilding can be found from the International Initiative for Impact Evaluation and the United Kingdom’s Department for International Development. Guidance on programming options to help prevent mass atrocities can be found from USAID.
Theory.of.change: If development assistance increases the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities
Name: Humanitarian aid
Description: The purpose of the assistance is humanitarian.
Inverse.factor.description: The purpose of the assistance is not humanitarian.
Description.Final_research: The purpose of the assistance is not humanitarian.

Short.description: A non-legal conflict management process facilitated by an external actor
Description_tool: Mediation is “a process of conflict management where disputants seek the assistance of, or accept an offer of help from, an individual, group, state or organization to settle their conflict or resolve their differences without resorting to physical force or invoking the authority of law” (Bercovitch et al. 1991, p. 8).
Theory.of.change: If mediation helps prevent or end an armed conflict, it would reduce the likelihood of mass atrocities because armed conflict is the strongest risk factor for mass atrocities (Bellamy 2011; Straus 2016).
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Name: High status target
Description: The target is a top leader or has high status.
Inverse.factor: Not a top leader or high status
Inverse.factor.description: The target is not a top leader or has low status.
Description.Final_research: The target is a top leader or has high status.

Short.description: Aid that promotes another state’s defense
Description_tool: Security assistance is support provided by a government in the form of “defense articles, military education and training, and other defense-related services to eligible foreign governments by grant, loan, credit, cash sales, or lease” (Office of the Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Army for Defense Exports and Cooperation).
Theory.of.change: If security assistance increases the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. In addition, if security assistance enables a state to provide physical protection to civilian populations, to increase costs to other armed actors of committing atrocities (e.g., by attacking them in response to atrocities), or to destroy or degrade other groups’ capacities to commit atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities, and (3) protecting vulnerable civilian populations.
Name: High-risk state
Description: The country under study exhibits a combination of characteristics that increase the likelihood of conflict onset, such as low GDP per capita and rule by anocracy.
Inverse.factor.description: The country under study does not exhibit characteristics that increase the likelihood of conflict onset.
Description.Final_research: The country under study does not exhibit characteristics that increase the likelihood of conflict onset.

Short.description: Prohibitions on weapons transfers
Description_tool: Arms embargoes prohibit arms transfers to a whole country (“blanket arms embargoes”), specific areas or forces within a country (“selective arms embargoes”), or individuals or groups regardless of location (“global arms embargoes”). Arms embargoes can target one or all sides of a conflict (“partial” and “impartial” arms embargoes, respectively) (SIPR 2007, pp. 2-3).
Theory.of.change: If arms embargoes deny potential perpetrators access to arms or raise the costs of acquiring arms, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities by constraining their capacity for violence. If arms embargoes increase the expected cost of committing mass atrocities, potential perpetrators would be more likely to choose alternative options (Brubaker and Dorfler 2017, pp. 2, 8).
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities
Name: Threat of use of tool
Description: The tool implementer threatens the use of the tool.
Inverse.factor: No threat of use of tool
Inverse.factor.description: The tool implementer does not threaten the use of the tool.
Description.Final_research: The tool implementer threatens the use of the tool.

Short.description: The official barring of legal proceedings against certain individuals or groups
Description_tool: An official amnesty is “an official legislative or executive act whereby criminal investigation or prosecution of an individual, a group or class of persons and/or certain offences is prospectively or retroactively barred, and any penalties cancelled” (ICRC 2017, p. 1).
Theory.of.change: If official amnesties increase the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, including by encouraging abusive leaders to give up power, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Name: Consistent implementation
Description: The tool is implemented consistently over time and across parties/perpetrator groups.
Inverse.factor.description: The tool is implemented inconsistently over time and across parties/perpetrator groups.
Description.Final_research: The tool is implemented consistently over time and across parties/perpetrator groups.

Short.description: Legal proceedings against suspected perpetrators of mass atrocities
Description_tool: Prosecutions of atrocity crimes are attempts to hold individuals criminally accountable for mass atrocities through national courts, the International Criminal Court, international tribunals, hybrid courts, or universal jurisdiction. This review is limited to analyses of the effects of actions to advance cases through courts, such as the referral of a case to a court, the opening of an investigation, indictments, arrest warrants, trials, and sentencing.
Theory.of.change: If prosecutions increase the expected costs to individuals of committing atrocities, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. In addition, if prosecutions satisfy the desire for justice for past atrocities, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities that might be committed to exact revenge on perpetrator groups. If prosecutions help remove individual perpetrators from positions of power or influence, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities by facilitating a transition to a less atrocity-prone political leadership.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Name: Consistent implementation
Description: The tool is implemented consistently over time and across parties/perpetrator groups.
Inverse.factor.description: The tool is implemented inconsistently over time and across parties/perpetrator groups.
Description.Final_research: The tool is implemented consistently over time and across parties/perpetrator groups.

Short.description: A non-legal conflict management process facilitated by an external actor
Description_tool: Mediation is “a process of conflict management where disputants seek the assistance of, or accept an offer of help from, an individual, group, state or organization to settle their conflict or resolve their differences without resorting to physical force or invoking the authority of law” (Bercovitch et al. 1991, p. 8).
Theory.of.change: If mediation helps prevent or end an armed conflict, it would reduce the likelihood of mass atrocities because armed conflict is the strongest risk factor for mass atrocities (Bellamy 2011; Straus 2016).
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Name: Conflict termination goals
Description: The tool implementer’s policy objective is to end the civil war or conflict.
Inverse.factor.description: The tool implementer’s policy objective is not to end the civil war or conflict.
Description.Final_research: The tool implementer’s policy objective is to end the civil war or conflict.

Name.Final_research: Tool addresses internal and external issues

Name: Democracy
Description: The country under study is a democracy. (Note - For our review, we assume that findings associated with autocracy or authoritarian regime type can be considered equivalent to findings associated with the absence of democracy.)
Inverse.factor.description: The country under study is an autocracy or authoritarian regime.
Description.Final_research: The country under study is a democracy. (Note - For our review, we assume that findings associated with autocracy or authoritarian regime type can be considered equivalent to findings associated with the absence of democracy.)

Name: Biased implementer or intervention
Description: The tool implementer or intervention is biased toward one party. Bias refers to the posture of the intervener, not necessarily prejudices that the intervener might hold about parties.
Inverse.factor.description: The tool implementer or intervention is not biased toward either party. Bias refers to the posture of the intervener, not necessarily prejudices that the intervener might hold about parties.
Description.Final_research: The tool implementer or intervention is not biased toward either party. Bias refers to the posture of the intervener, not necessarily prejudices that the intervener might hold about parties.

Inverse.factor.description: The target lacks access to resources, such as oil or gemstones, to continue the conflict.

Name: Economic shock
Description: The country under study has recently experienced an economic shock.
Inverse.factor.description: The country under study has not recently experienced an economic shock.
Description.Final_research: The country under study has recently experienced an economic shock.

Short.description: Public condemnation of perpetrators of mass atrocities
Description_tool: Naming and shaming is the publicizing of “rights-based violations and their perpetrators (naming) and bring[ing] more pressure to bear on perpetrators of rights violations to change their behavior (shaming)” (Krain 2012, p. 575; Keck and Sikkink 1998).
Theory.of.change: If naming and shaming imposes reputational costs on perpetrators and/or increases the expected future costs of committing atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities (Krain 2012; DeMeritt 2012). If naming and shaming imposes reputational and political costs that encourage perpetrators to consider exiting their positions of power, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities by helping facilitate a political transition.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, or (2) facilitating a political transition
Name: Highly developed state
Description: The country under study is highly developed.
Inverse.factor.description: The country under study is not highly developed.
Description.Final_research: The country under study is not highly developed.

Name.Final_research: Target is a severe human rights violator

Name.Final_research: Target relies on international trade and investment
Short.description: Public condemnation of perpetrators of mass atrocities
Description_tool: Naming and shaming is the publicizing of “rights-based violations and their perpetrators (naming) and bring[ing] more pressure to bear on perpetrators of rights violations to change their behavior (shaming)” (Krain 2012, p. 575; Keck and Sikkink 1998).
Theory.of.change: If naming and shaming imposes reputational costs on perpetrators and/or increases the expected future costs of committing atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities (Krain 2012; DeMeritt 2012). If naming and shaming imposes reputational and political costs that encourage perpetrators to consider exiting their positions of power, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities by helping facilitate a political transition.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, or (2) facilitating a political transition
Name: Target relies on international trade and investment
Dedoose.name_factor: Reliance on international trade and investment
Description: The target relies on international trade or investment.
Inverse.factor: Target does not rely on international trade or investment

Description.Final_research: The target relies on international trade or investment.

If naming and shaming imposes reputational and political costs that encourage perpetrators to consider exiting their positions of power, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities by helping facilitate a political transition.

Name: Democracy
Description: The country under study is a democracy. (Note - For our review, we assume that findings associated with autocracy or authoritarian regime type can be considered equivalent to findings associated with the absence of democracy.)
Inverse.factor.description: The country under study is an autocracy or authoritarian regime.
Description.Final_research: The country under study is an autocracy or authoritarian regime.

Short.description: Public condemnation of perpetrators of mass atrocities
Description_tool: Naming and shaming is the publicizing of “rights-based violations and their perpetrators (naming) and bring[ing] more pressure to bear on perpetrators of rights violations to change their behavior (shaming)” (Krain 2012, p. 575; Keck and Sikkink 1998).
Theory.of.change: If naming and shaming imposes reputational costs on perpetrators and/or increases the expected future costs of committing atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities (Krain 2012; DeMeritt 2012). If naming and shaming imposes reputational and political costs that encourage perpetrators to consider exiting their positions of power, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities by helping facilitate a political transition.

Name: Local support for tool
Description: Most of the local population and/or local civil society supports the use of the tool and perceives its use as legitimate.
Inverse.factor.description: There is a low degree of local population support or civil society mobilization for the use or goals of the tool, and/or the local population perceives the use of the tool as illegitimate.
Description.Final_research: Most of the local population and/or local civil society supports the use of the tool and perceives its use as legitimate.

Short.description: A non-legal conflict management process facilitated by an external actor
Description_tool: Mediation is “a process of conflict management where disputants seek the assistance of, or accept an offer of help from, an individual, group, state or organization to settle their conflict or resolve their differences without resorting to physical force or invoking the authority of law” (Bercovitch et al. 1991, p. 8).
Theory.of.change: If mediation helps prevent or end an armed conflict, it would reduce the likelihood of mass atrocities because armed conflict is the strongest risk factor for mass atrocities (Bellamy 2011; Straus 2016).
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Name: Ethnic exclusion or polarization
Description: The state where mass atrocities are occurring is characterized by high levels of ethnic exclusion or ethnic polarization.
Inverse.factor.description: The country under study is characterized by low levels of ethnic exclusion or ethnic polarization.
Description.Final_research: The country under study is characterized by low levels of ethnic exclusion or ethnic polarization.

Name: Imbalance of wealth between conflict parties
Description: There is an imbalance of wealth between conflict parties.
Inverse.factor: Balance of wealth between conflict parties
Inverse.factor.description: There is a balance of wealth between conflict parties.
Description.Final_research: There is an imbalance of wealth between conflict parties.

Short.description: Aid that promotes another state’s defense
Description_tool: Security assistance is support provided by a government in the form of “defense articles, military education and training, and other defense-related services to eligible foreign governments by grant, loan, credit, cash sales, or lease” (Office of the Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Army for Defense Exports and Cooperation).
Theory.of.change: If security assistance increases the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. In addition, if security assistance enables a state to provide physical protection to civilian populations, to increase costs to other armed actors of committing atrocities (e.g., by attacking them in response to atrocities), or to destroy or degrade other groups’ capacities to commit atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities, and (3) protecting vulnerable civilian populations.
Name: History of conflict
Description: The parties to the conflict or the country under study has a history of violent conflict.
Inverse.factor.description: Neither the parties to the conflict nor the country under study has a history of violent conflict.
Description.Final_research: The parties to the conflict or the country under study has a history of violent conflict.

Description_tool: Security assistance is support provided by a government in the form of “defense articles, military education and training, and other defense-related services to eligible foreign governments by grant, loan, credit, cash sales, or lease” (Office of the Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Army for Defense Exports and Cooperation).

Name: High quantity of support
Description: The quantity of external support to the state actor or non-state armed group results in a large increase in the group’s capabilities.
Inverse.factor.description: The quantity of external support to the state actor or non-state armed group does not result in a large increase in the group’s capabilities.
Description.Final_research: The quantity of external support to the state actor or non-state armed group does not result in a large increase in the group’s capabilities.

Theory.of.change: If security assistance increases the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities, and (3) protecting vulnerable civilian populations.
Name: Ongoing armed conflict
Description: There is an ongoing armed conflict in the country under study.
Inverse.factor.description: There is no ongoing armed conflict in the country under study.
Description.Final_research: There is an ongoing armed conflict in the country under study.

Short.description: Aid that promotes economic growth, welfare, and humanitarian relief
Description_tool: Development assistance is “government aid that promotes and specifically targets the economic development and welfare of developing countries” (OECD). Development assistance is typically organized into sectors, including democracy, rights, and governance; economic growth; health; education; and humanitarian assistance (USAID). Our research review includes studies of the linkage between development assistance of any or all sectors with mass atrocities or closely related outcomes. As such, it is not a detailed review of alternative program-level interventions. Research reviews of programming options in conflict prevention and peacebuilding can be found from the International Initiative for Impact Evaluation and the United Kingdom’s Department for International Development. Guidance on programming options to help prevent mass atrocities can be found from USAID.
Theory.of.change: If development assistance increases the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities
Name: Clear policy objectives
Description: The implementer's objectives in using the tool are clear.
Inverse.factor.description: The implementer's objectives in using the tool are unclear.
Description.Final_research: The implementer's objectives in using the tool are clear.

Name: Aid-dependent target
Description: The target is dependent on foreign aid.
Inverse.factor.description: The target is not dependent on foreign aid.
Description.Final_research: The target is dependent on foreign aid.

Short.description: Aid provided by a foreign state to a rebel group
Description_tool: Support to non-state armed groups is assistance--including “the provision of weapons, funds, logistics, military training and access to intelligence and sanctuaries" (Karlen 2017, p. 16)--provided by a foreign state to a non-state armed group (often referred to as a rebel group). This review does not include analyses of direct military intervention in support of a non-state armed group.
Theory.of.change: If support to a non-state armed group enables the group to provide physical protection to civilian populations, to increase costs to other armed actors of committing atrocities (e.g., by attacking them in response to atrocities), or to destroy or degrade other groups’ capacities to commit atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. In addition, if support to a non-state armed group enables it to defeat an abusive government and facilitate a political transition, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities, (3) protecting vulnerable civilian populations, and (4) facilitating a political transition.
Name: High quantity of support
Description: The quantity of external support to the state actor or non-state armed group results in a large increase in the group’s capabilities.
Inverse.factor.description: The quantity of external support to the state actor or non-state armed group does not result in a large increase in the group’s capabilities.
Description.Final_research: The quantity of external support to the state actor or non-state armed group does not result in a large increase in the group’s capabilities.

Our research review includes studies of the linkage between development assistance of any or all sectors with mass atrocities or closely related outcomes. Name: Anocracy or hybrid regime
Description: The country under study is an anocracy or hybrid regime.
Inverse.factor.description: The country under study is not an anocracy or hybrid regime.
Description.Final_research: The country under study is an anocracy or hybrid regime.

Short.description: Prohibitions on weapons transfers
Description_tool: Arms embargoes prohibit arms transfers to a whole country (“blanket arms embargoes”), specific areas or forces within a country (“selective arms embargoes”), or individuals or groups regardless of location (“global arms embargoes”). Arms embargoes can target one or all sides of a conflict (“partial” and “impartial” arms embargoes, respectively) (SIPR 2007, pp. 2-3).
Theory.of.change: If arms embargoes deny potential perpetrators access to arms or raise the costs of acquiring arms, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities by constraining their capacity for violence. If arms embargoes increase the expected cost of committing mass atrocities, potential perpetrators would be more likely to choose alternative options (Brubaker and Dorfler 2017, pp. 2, 8).
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities
Name: Monitoring and adjustment
Description: The success of the tool is monitored and the tool is adjusted to maximize success.
Inverse.factor.description: The success of the tool is not monitored nor is the tool adjusted to maximize success.
Description.Final_research: The success of the tool is monitored and the tool is adjusted to maximize success.

Short.description: The official barring of legal proceedings against certain individuals or groups
Description_tool: An official amnesty is “an official legislative or executive act whereby criminal investigation or prosecution of an individual, a group or class of persons and/or certain offences is prospectively or retroactively barred, and any penalties cancelled” (ICRC 2017, p. 1).
Theory.of.change: If official amnesties increase the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, including by encouraging abusive leaders to give up power, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Name: Strong government
Description: The national government is strong, or has a high degree of resilience, adaptability, military experience, power, or territorial control.
Inverse.factor.description: The government in the conflict is weak or has a low degree of resilience, adaptability, military experience, power, or territorial control.
Description.Final_research: The national government is strong, or has a high degree of resilience, adaptability, military experience, power, or territorial control.

Description: The target is a state actor or state group.
Inverse.factor.description: The target is a non-state actor or non-state group.
Description.Final_research: The target is a state actor or state group.

Short.description: Aid that promotes economic growth, welfare, and humanitarian relief
Description_tool: Development assistance is “government aid that promotes and specifically targets the economic development and welfare of developing countries” (OECD). Development assistance is typically organized into sectors, including democracy, rights, and governance; economic growth; health; education; and humanitarian assistance (USAID). Our research review includes studies of the linkage between development assistance of any or all sectors with mass atrocities or closely related outcomes. As such, it is not a detailed review of alternative program-level interventions. Research reviews of programming options in conflict prevention and peacebuilding can be found from the International Initiative for Impact Evaluation and the United Kingdom’s Department for International Development. Guidance on programming options to help prevent mass atrocities can be found from USAID.
Theory.of.change: If development assistance increases the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities
Name: Well-informed implementer
Description: The tool implementer is well-versed in the political and social context in which the conflict is occurring, or has credible information about the intentions or capabilities of the target.
Inverse.factor.description: The tool implementer is poorly-versed in the political and social context in which the conflict is occurring, or lacks credible information about the intentions or capabilities of the target.
Description.Final_research: The tool implementer is well-versed in the political and social context in which the conflict is occurring, or has credible information about the intentions or capabilities of the target.

Short.description: Prohibitions on weapons transfers
Description_tool: Arms embargoes prohibit arms transfers to a whole country (“blanket arms embargoes”), specific areas or forces within a country (“selective arms embargoes”), or individuals or groups regardless of location (“global arms embargoes”). Arms embargoes can target one or all sides of a conflict (“partial” and “impartial” arms embargoes, respectively) (SIPR 2007, pp. 2-3).
Theory.of.change: If arms embargoes deny potential perpetrators access to arms or raise the costs of acquiring arms, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities by constraining their capacity for violence. If arms embargoes increase the expected cost of committing mass atrocities, potential perpetrators would be more likely to choose alternative options (Brubaker and Dorfler 2017, pp. 2, 8).
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities
Name: Neighbor implementer
Description: The target and the tool implementer are in the same region or members of the same regional organization.
Inverse.factor.description: The target and the tool implementer are not in the same region or members of the same regional organization.
Description.Final_research: The target and the tool implementer are in the same region or members of the same regional organization.

Short.description: Aid that promotes another state’s defense
Description_tool: Security assistance is support provided by a government in the form of “defense articles, military education and training, and other defense-related services to eligible foreign governments by grant, loan, credit, cash sales, or lease” (Office of the Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Army for Defense Exports and Cooperation).
Theory.of.change: If security assistance increases the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. In addition, if security assistance enables a state to provide physical protection to civilian populations, to increase costs to other armed actors of committing atrocities (e.g., by attacking them in response to atrocities), or to destroy or degrade other groups’ capacities to commit atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities, and (3) protecting vulnerable civilian populations.
Name: Democracy
Description: The country under study is a democracy. (Note - For our review, we assume that findings associated with autocracy or authoritarian regime type can be considered equivalent to findings associated with the absence of democracy.)
Inverse.factor.description: The country under study is an autocracy or authoritarian regime.
Description.Final_research: The country under study is a democracy. (Note - For our review, we assume that findings associated with autocracy or authoritarian regime type can be considered equivalent to findings associated with the absence of democracy.)

Short.description: Aid that promotes another state’s defense
Description_tool: Security assistance is support provided by a government in the form of “defense articles, military education and training, and other defense-related services to eligible foreign governments by grant, loan, credit, cash sales, or lease” (Office of the Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Army for Defense Exports and Cooperation).
Theory.of.change: If security assistance increases the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. In addition, if security assistance enables a state to provide physical protection to civilian populations, to increase costs to other armed actors of committing atrocities (e.g., by attacking them in response to atrocities), or to destroy or degrade other groups’ capacities to commit atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities, and (3) protecting vulnerable civilian populations.
Name: Established target
Description: The target is a well-established or old group.
Inverse.factor.description: The target is a poorly-established or new group.
Description.Final_research: The target is a well-established or old group.

Short.description: Aid that promotes economic growth, welfare, and humanitarian relief
Description_tool: Development assistance is “government aid that promotes and specifically targets the economic development and welfare of developing countries” (OECD). Development assistance is typically organized into sectors, including democracy, rights, and governance; economic growth; health; education; and humanitarian assistance (USAID). Our research review includes studies of the linkage between development assistance of any or all sectors with mass atrocities or closely related outcomes. As such, it is not a detailed review of alternative program-level interventions. Research reviews of programming options in conflict prevention and peacebuilding can be found from the International Initiative for Impact Evaluation and the United Kingdom’s Department for International Development. Guidance on programming options to help prevent mass atrocities can be found from USAID.
Theory.of.change: If development assistance increases the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities
Name: Ethnic exclusion or polarization
Description: The state where mass atrocities are occurring is characterized by high levels of ethnic exclusion or ethnic polarization.
Inverse.factor.description: The country under study is characterized by low levels of ethnic exclusion or ethnic polarization.
Description.Final_research: The state where mass atrocities are occurring is characterized by high levels of ethnic exclusion or ethnic polarization.

Short.description: Aid that promotes economic growth, welfare, and humanitarian relief
Description_tool: Development assistance is “government aid that promotes and specifically targets the economic development and welfare of developing countries” (OECD). Development assistance is typically organized into sectors, including democracy, rights, and governance; economic growth; health; education; and humanitarian assistance (USAID). Guidance on programming options to help prevent mass atrocities can be found from USAID.
Theory.of.change: If development assistance increases the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities
Name: Inflation
Description: The economy of the country under study is experiencing inflation.
Inverse.factor.description: The economy of the country under study is not experiencing inflation.
Description.Final_research: The economy of the country under study is not experiencing inflation.

Short.description: Public condemnation of perpetrators of mass atrocities
Description_tool: Naming and shaming is the publicizing of “rights-based violations and their perpetrators (naming) and bring[ing] more pressure to bear on perpetrators of rights violations to change their behavior (shaming)” (Krain 2012, p. 575; Keck and Sikkink 1998).
Theory.of.change: If naming and shaming imposes reputational costs on perpetrators and/or increases the expected future costs of committing atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities (Krain 2012; DeMeritt 2012). If naming and shaming imposes reputational and political costs that encourage perpetrators to consider exiting their positions of power, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities by helping facilitate a political transition.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, or (2) facilitating a political transition
Name: Aid-dependent target
Description: The target is dependent on foreign aid.
Inverse.factor.description: The target is not dependent on foreign aid.
Description.Final_research: The target is dependent on foreign aid.

Short.description: Aid provided by a foreign state to a rebel group
Description_tool: Support to non-state armed groups is assistance--including “the provision of weapons, funds, logistics, military training and access to intelligence and sanctuaries" (Karlen 2017, p. 16)--provided by a foreign state to a non-state armed group (often referred to as a rebel group). This review does not include analyses of direct military intervention in support of a non-state armed group.
Theory.of.change: If support to a non-state armed group enables the group to provide physical protection to civilian populations, to increase costs to other armed actors of committing atrocities (e.g., by attacking them in response to atrocities), or to destroy or degrade other groups’ capacities to commit atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. In addition, if support to a non-state armed group enables it to defeat an abusive government and facilitate a political transition, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities, (3) protecting vulnerable civilian populations, and (4) facilitating a political transition.
Name: Diaspora implementer
Description: The tool implementer is members of the diaspora.
Inverse.factor.description: The tool implementer is not members of the diaspora.
Description.Final_research: The tool implementer is members of the diaspora.

Short.description: Aid provided by a foreign state to a rebel group
Description_tool: Support to non-state armed groups is assistance--including “the provision of weapons, funds, logistics, military training and access to intelligence and sanctuaries" (Karlen 2017, p. 16)--provided by a foreign state to a non-state armed group (often referred to as a rebel group). Name: State implementer
Description: The tool implementer is a foreign government.
Inverse.factor.description: The tool implementer is not a foreign government.
Description.Final_research: The tool implementer is not a foreign government.

Short.description: Aid provided by a foreign state to a rebel group
Description_tool: Support to non-state armed groups is assistance--including “the provision of weapons, funds, logistics, military training and access to intelligence and sanctuaries" (Karlen 2017, p. 16)--provided by a foreign state to a non-state armed group (often referred to as a rebel group). Name: Non-governmental implementer
Description: The tool implementer is a non-governmental organization.
Inverse.factor.description: The tool implementer is not a non-governmental organization.
Description.Final_research: The tool implementer is a non-governmental organization.

Short.description: The official barring of legal proceedings against certain individuals or groups
Description_tool: An official amnesty is “an official legislative or executive act whereby criminal investigation or prosecution of an individual, a group or class of persons and/or certain offences is prospectively or retroactively barred, and any penalties cancelled” (ICRC 2017, p. 1).
Theory.of.change: If official amnesties increase the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, including by encouraging abusive leaders to give up power, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Name: Leaders do not join amnesty
Description: The leaders of the country or rebel group under study do not participate in the amnesty.
Inverse.factor.description: The leaders of the country or rebel group under study participate in the amnesty.
Description.Final_research: The leaders of the country or rebel group under study participate in the amnesty.

Short.description: Coercive measures that target the economic capacity of a state
Description_tool: Comprehensive economic sanctions are “coercive economic measures taken against a target to bring about a change in behavior” (CRS 2021, p. 1). Comprehensive sanctions “block the government and include broad-based trade restrictions” (Treasury OFAC).
Theory.of.change: If comprehensive economic sanctions raise the costs on the commission of atrocities, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. These costs can be material (e.g., by increasing the relative economic strength of the opposition), reputational, or political (e.g., by contributing to social upheaval) (Wood 2008, p. 491). In addition, if comprehensive economic sanctions degrade perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities by denying them or raising the costs of acquiring critical means, such as funds, arms, and other enabling technological goods, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities
Name: Legal lootable resources
Description: The country is experiencing a conflict that involves legal lootable resources.
Inverse.factor.description: The country is experiencing a conflict that does not involve legal lootable resources.
Description.Final_research: The country is experiencing a conflict that involves legal lootable resources.

Description_tool: Comprehensive economic sanctions are “coercive economic measures taken against a target to bring about a change in behavior” (CRS 2021, p. 1). Comprehensive sanctions “block the government and include broad-based trade restrictions” (Treasury OFAC).

Description: The tool implementer provides troops to the non-state armed group.
Inverse.factor.description: The tool implementer does not provide troops to the non-state armed group.
Description.Final_research: The tool implementer provides troops to the non-state armed group.

Theory.of.change: If comprehensive economic sanctions raise the costs on the commission of atrocities, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. Name: Concurrent use of multiple tools
Description: The tool implementer or other actors are simultaneously implementing other tools that are consistent with the goals of the tool.
Inverse.factor.description: No actors are implementing tools that are consistent with the goals of the tool.
Description.Final_research: The tool implementer or other actors are simultaneously implementing other tools that are consistent with the goals of the tool.

outcomes: Conflict, Human rights violations, Mass atrocities
Short.description: Legal proceedings against suspected perpetrators of mass atrocities
Description_tool: Prosecutions of atrocity crimes are attempts to hold individuals criminally accountable for mass atrocities through national courts, the International Criminal Court, international tribunals, hybrid courts, or universal jurisdiction. This review is limited to analyses of the effects of actions to advance cases through courts, such as the referral of a case to a court, the opening of an investigation, indictments, arrest warrants, trials, and sentencing.
Theory.of.change: If prosecutions increase the expected costs to individuals of committing atrocities, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. In addition, if prosecutions satisfy the desire for justice for past atrocities, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities that might be committed to exact revenge on perpetrator groups. If prosecutions help remove individual perpetrators from positions of power or influence, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities by facilitating a transition to a less atrocity-prone political leadership.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Name: High status target
Description: The target is a top leader or has high status.
Inverse.factor: Not a top leader or high status
Inverse.factor.description: The target is not a top leader or has low status.
Description.Final_research: The target is a top leader or has high status.

Description.Final_research: The target cares about their reputation among domestic and international audiences.

Name: Consistent implementation
Description: The tool is implemented consistently over time and across parties/perpetrator groups.
Inverse.factor.description: The tool is implemented inconsistently over time and across parties/perpetrator groups.
Description.Final_research: The tool is implemented consistently over time and across parties/perpetrator groups.

Short.description: Severing or downgrading diplomatic relations to signal disapproval
Description_tool: Diplomatic sanctions include “severing formal diplomatic ties with a country or significantly downgrading ties from the normal level of diplomatic activity for foreign policy purposes” (Maller 2009, p. 512). Diplomatic sanctions may specifically entail not recognizing a regime in public statements, withdrawing staff from or closing an embassy, “restrictions on travel for specific leaders” (MacGregor and Bowles 2012, p. 445), and “suspension of membership or expulsion from international or regional bodies” (ICISS 2001, p. 31). Diplomatic sanctions are intended to “signal disapproval of the target regime's behaviour, and also to signal the possibility of subsequent punitive measures should that behaviour not change” (Krain 2014, p. 27).
Theory.of.change: If diplomatic sanctions impose reputational costs on potential perpetrators and/or increase their expectation that external actors will impose other costs in the future in response to atrocities, they would reduce the likelihood of mass atrocities. In addition, if diplomatic sanctions damage an abusive leader’s domestic standing, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities by helping facilitate a political transition.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (4) facilitating a political transition.
Name: Concurrent use of multiple tools
Description: The tool implementer or other actors are simultaneously implementing other tools that are consistent with the goals of the tool.
Inverse.factor.description: No actors are implementing tools that are consistent with the goals of the tool.
Description.Final_research: The tool implementer or other actors are simultaneously implementing other tools that are consistent with the goals of the tool.

Name.Final_research: Absence of a peace agreement involving amnesties

Name: Existence of a peace agreement involving amnesties
Description: There is a peace agreement involving amnesties.
Inverse.factor: Absence of a peace agreement involving amnesties
Inverse.factor.description: There is no peace agreement involving amnesties in the conflict.
Description.Final_research: There is no peace agreement involving amnesties in the conflict.

Name: Early implementation
Description: The tool is implemented early in the conflict or rapidly after the appearance of early warning signs or occurrence of mass atrocities.
Inverse.factor.description: The tool is implemented late in the conflict or slowly after the appearance of early warning signs or occurrence of mass atrocities.
Description.Final_research: The tool is implemented early in the conflict or rapidly after the appearance of early warning signs or occurrence of mass atrocities.

Name.Final_research: Absence of external assistance or foreign troops

Description_tool: Support to non-state armed groups is assistance--including “the provision of weapons, funds, logistics, military training and access to intelligence and sanctuaries" (Karlen 2017, p. 16)--provided by a foreign state to a non-state armed group (often referred to as a rebel group). Name: External assistance or foreign troops
Description: There are foreign troops active in the ongoing conflict situation or external actors are offering assistance to the conflict parties.
Inverse.factor: Absence of external assistance or foreign troops
Inverse.factor.description: There are no foreign troops active in the ongoing conflict situation nor are external actors offering assistance to the conflict parties.
Description.Final_research: There are no foreign troops active in the ongoing conflict situation nor are external actors offering assistance to the conflict parties.

Short.description: A non-legal conflict management process facilitated by an external actor
Description_tool: Mediation is “a process of conflict management where disputants seek the assistance of, or accept an offer of help from, an individual, group, state or organization to settle their conflict or resolve their differences without resorting to physical force or invoking the authority of law” (Bercovitch et al. 1991, p. 8).
Theory.of.change: If mediation helps prevent or end an armed conflict, it would reduce the likelihood of mass atrocities because armed conflict is the strongest risk factor for mass atrocities (Bellamy 2011; Straus 2016).
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Name: Multiple mediators
Description: There are multiple mediators mediating the conflict.
Inverse.factor.description: There is a single mediator mediating the conflict.
Description.Final_research: There is a single mediator mediating the conflict.

Short.description: A non-legal conflict management process facilitated by an external actor
Description_tool: Mediation is “a process of conflict management where disputants seek the assistance of, or accept an offer of help from, an individual, group, state or organization to settle their conflict or resolve their differences without resorting to physical force or invoking the authority of law” (Bercovitch et al. 1991, p. 8).
Theory.of.change: If mediation helps prevent or end an armed conflict, it would reduce the likelihood of mass atrocities because armed conflict is the strongest risk factor for mass atrocities (Bellamy 2011; Straus 2016).
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Name: Decisive mediation strategy
Description: The mediator deploys a decisive strategy.
Inverse.factor.description: The mediator deploys an indecisive strategy.
Description.Final_research: The mediator deploys a decisive strategy.

Short.description: The official barring of legal proceedings against certain individuals or groups
Description_tool: An official amnesty is “an official legislative or executive act whereby criminal investigation or prosecution of an individual, a group or class of persons and/or certain offences is prospectively or retroactively barred, and any penalties cancelled” (ICRC 2017, p. 1).
Theory.of.change: If official amnesties increase the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, including by encouraging abusive leaders to give up power, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Name: Democracy
Description: The country under study is a democracy. (Note - For our review, we assume that findings associated with autocracy or authoritarian regime type can be considered equivalent to findings associated with the absence of democracy.)
Inverse.factor.description: The country under study is an autocracy or authoritarian regime.
Description.Final_research: The country under study is an autocracy or authoritarian regime.

Short.description: A non-legal conflict management process facilitated by an external actor
Description_tool: Mediation is “a process of conflict management where disputants seek the assistance of, or accept an offer of help from, an individual, group, state or organization to settle their conflict or resolve their differences without resorting to physical force or invoking the authority of law” (Bercovitch et al. 1991, p. 8).
Theory.of.change: If mediation helps prevent or end an armed conflict, it would reduce the likelihood of mass atrocities because armed conflict is the strongest risk factor for mass atrocities (Bellamy 2011; Straus 2016).
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.

Description: The tool implementer is domestic, i.e., from the target state.
Inverse.factor.description: The tool implementer is foreign, i.e., not from the target state.
Description.Final_research: The tool implementer is domestic, i.e., from the target state.

Short.description: A non-legal conflict management process facilitated by an external actor
Description_tool: Mediation is “a process of conflict management where disputants seek the assistance of, or accept an offer of help from, an individual, group, state or organization to settle their conflict or resolve their differences without resorting to physical force or invoking the authority of law” (Bercovitch et al. 1991, p. 8).

Name: Western implementer
Description: The tool implementer is Western.

Description.Final_research: The tool implementer is Western.

Short.description: The official barring of legal proceedings against certain individuals or groups
Description_tool: An official amnesty is “an official legislative or executive act whereby criminal investigation or prosecution of an individual, a group or class of persons and/or certain offences is prospectively or retroactively barred, and any penalties cancelled” (ICRC 2017, p. 1).
Theory.of.change: If official amnesties increase the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, including by encouraging abusive leaders to give up power, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Name: Amnesty includes relevant parties
Description: The amnesty agreement includes relevant parties to the conflict.
Inverse.factor: Amnesty does not include relevant parties
Inverse.factor.description: The amnesty agreement does not include relevant parties to the conflict.
Description.Final_research: The amnesty agreement includes relevant parties to the conflict.

Short.description: Coercive measures that target the economic capacity of a state
Description_tool: Comprehensive economic sanctions are “coercive economic measures taken against a target to bring about a change in behavior” (CRS 2021, p. 1). Comprehensive sanctions “block the government and include broad-based trade restrictions” (Treasury OFAC).
Theory.of.change: If comprehensive economic sanctions raise the costs on the commission of atrocities, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. These costs can be material (e.g., by increasing the relative economic strength of the opposition), reputational, or political (e.g., by contributing to social upheaval) (Wood 2008, p. 491). In addition, if comprehensive economic sanctions degrade perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities by denying them or raising the costs of acquiring critical means, such as funds, arms, and other enabling technological goods, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities
Name: Democracy
Description: The country under study is a democracy. (Note - For our review, we assume that findings associated with autocracy or authoritarian regime type can be considered equivalent to findings associated with the absence of democracy.)

Description.Final_research: The country under study is a democracy. (Note - For our review, we assume that findings associated with autocracy or authoritarian regime type can be considered equivalent to findings associated with the absence of democracy.)

Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Name: Indictment
Description: There has been an indictment.
Inverse.factor.description: There has not been an indictment.
Description.Final_research: There has not been an indictment.

Short.description: A non-legal conflict management process facilitated by an external actor
Description_tool: Mediation is “a process of conflict management where disputants seek the assistance of, or accept an offer of help from, an individual, group, state or organization to settle their conflict or resolve their differences without resorting to physical force or invoking the authority of law” (Bercovitch et al. 1991, p. 8).
Theory.of.change: If mediation helps prevent or end an armed conflict, it would reduce the likelihood of mass atrocities because armed conflict is the strongest risk factor for mass atrocities (Bellamy 2011; Straus 2016).
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Name: High ethnic diversity
Description: The country under study has a high degree of ethnic diversity.
Inverse.factor.description: The country under study has a low degree of ethnic diversity.
Description.Final_research: The country under study has a low degree of ethnic diversity.

Short.description: Public condemnation of perpetrators of mass atrocities
Description_tool: Naming and shaming is the publicizing of “rights-based violations and their perpetrators (naming) and bring[ing] more pressure to bear on perpetrators of rights violations to change their behavior (shaming)” (Krain 2012, p. 575; Keck and Sikkink 1998).
Theory.of.change: If naming and shaming imposes reputational costs on perpetrators and/or increases the expected future costs of committing atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities (Krain 2012; DeMeritt 2012). If naming and shaming imposes reputational and political costs that encourage perpetrators to consider exiting their positions of power, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities by helping facilitate a political transition.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, or (2) facilitating a political transition
Name: Concurrent use of multiple tools
Description: The tool implementer or other actors are simultaneously implementing other tools that are consistent with the goals of the tool.
Inverse.factor.description: No actors are implementing tools that are consistent with the goals of the tool.
Description.Final_research: The tool implementer or other actors are simultaneously implementing other tools that are consistent with the goals of the tool.

Name.Final_research: Absence of external assistance or foreign troops
Short.description: Aid that promotes economic growth, welfare, and humanitarian relief
Description_tool: Development assistance is “government aid that promotes and specifically targets the economic development and welfare of developing countries” (OECD). Development assistance is typically organized into sectors, including democracy, rights, and governance; economic growth; health; education; and humanitarian assistance (USAID). Our research review includes studies of the linkage between development assistance of any or all sectors with mass atrocities or closely related outcomes. As such, it is not a detailed review of alternative program-level interventions. Research reviews of programming options in conflict prevention and peacebuilding can be found from the International Initiative for Impact Evaluation and the United Kingdom’s Department for International Development. Guidance on programming options to help prevent mass atrocities can be found from USAID.
Theory.of.change: If development assistance increases the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities
Name: External assistance or foreign troops
Description: There are foreign troops active in the ongoing conflict situation or external actors are offering assistance to the conflict parties.
Inverse.factor: Absence of external assistance or foreign troops
Inverse.factor.description: There are no foreign troops active in the ongoing conflict situation nor are external actors offering assistance to the conflict parties.
Description.Final_research: There are no foreign troops active in the ongoing conflict situation nor are external actors offering assistance to the conflict parties.

Short.description: Aid that promotes economic growth, welfare, and humanitarian relief
Description_tool: Development assistance is “government aid that promotes and specifically targets the economic development and welfare of developing countries” (OECD). Development assistance is typically organized into sectors, including democracy, rights, and governance; economic growth; health; education; and humanitarian assistance (USAID). Our research review includes studies of the linkage between development assistance of any or all sectors with mass atrocities or closely related outcomes. As such, it is not a detailed review of alternative program-level interventions. Research reviews of programming options in conflict prevention and peacebuilding can be found from the International Initiative for Impact Evaluation and the United Kingdom’s Department for International Development. Guidance on programming options to help prevent mass atrocities can be found from USAID.
Theory.of.change: If development assistance increases the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities
Name: Early implementation
Description: The tool is implemented early in the conflict or rapidly after the appearance of early warning signs or occurrence of mass atrocities.
Inverse.factor.description: The tool is implemented late in the conflict or slowly after the appearance of early warning signs or occurrence of mass atrocities.
Description.Final_research: The tool is implemented early in the conflict or rapidly after the appearance of early warning signs or occurrence of mass atrocities.

Short.description: Legal proceedings against suspected perpetrators of mass atrocities
Description_tool: Prosecutions of atrocity crimes are attempts to hold individuals criminally accountable for mass atrocities through national courts, the International Criminal Court, international tribunals, hybrid courts, or universal jurisdiction. This review is limited to analyses of the effects of actions to advance cases through courts, such as the referral of a case to a court, the opening of an investigation, indictments, arrest warrants, trials, and sentencing.
Theory.of.change: If prosecutions increase the expected costs to individuals of committing atrocities, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. In addition, if prosecutions satisfy the desire for justice for past atrocities, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities that might be committed to exact revenge on perpetrator groups. If prosecutions help remove individual perpetrators from positions of power or influence, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities by facilitating a transition to a less atrocity-prone political leadership.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Name: National atrocity prevention efforts
Description: The government of the country under study is concurrently taking other actions to help prevent mass atrocities.
Inverse.factor.description: The government of the country under study is not implementing other tools that are consistent with the goals of the tool.
Description.Final_research: The government of the country under study is concurrently taking other actions to help prevent mass atrocities.

Short.description: Coercive measures that target the economic capacity of a state
Description_tool: Comprehensive economic sanctions are “coercive economic measures taken against a target to bring about a change in behavior” (CRS 2021, p. 1). Comprehensive sanctions “block the government and include broad-based trade restrictions” (Treasury OFAC).
Theory.of.change: If comprehensive economic sanctions raise the costs on the commission of atrocities, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. These costs can be material (e.g., by increasing the relative economic strength of the opposition), reputational, or political (e.g., by contributing to social upheaval) (Wood 2008, p. 491). In addition, if comprehensive economic sanctions degrade perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities by denying them or raising the costs of acquiring critical means, such as funds, arms, and other enabling technological goods, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities
Name: Target has access to resources
Description: The target has access to resources, such as oil or gemstones.
Inverse.factor.description: The target lacks access to resources, such as oil or gemstones, to continue the conflict.
Description.Final_research: The target lacks access to resources, such as oil or gemstones, to continue the conflict.

Name.Final_research: Absence of external assistance or foreign troops

Description_tool: Comprehensive economic sanctions are “coercive economic measures taken against a target to bring about a change in behavior” (CRS 2021, p. 1). Comprehensive sanctions “block the government and include broad-based trade restrictions” (Treasury OFAC).
Theory.of.change: If comprehensive economic sanctions raise the costs on the commission of atrocities, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. Name: External assistance or foreign troops
Description: There are foreign troops active in the ongoing conflict situation or external actors are offering assistance to the conflict parties.
Inverse.factor: Absence of external assistance or foreign troops
Inverse.factor.description: There are no foreign troops active in the ongoing conflict situation nor are external actors offering assistance to the conflict parties.
Description.Final_research: There are no foreign troops active in the ongoing conflict situation nor are external actors offering assistance to the conflict parties.

Short.description: Severing or downgrading diplomatic relations to signal disapproval
Description_tool: Diplomatic sanctions include “severing formal diplomatic ties with a country or significantly downgrading ties from the normal level of diplomatic activity for foreign policy purposes” (Maller 2009, p. 512). Diplomatic sanctions may specifically entail not recognizing a regime in public statements, withdrawing staff from or closing an embassy, “restrictions on travel for specific leaders” (MacGregor and Bowles 2012, p. 445), and “suspension of membership or expulsion from international or regional bodies” (ICISS 2001, p. 31). Diplomatic sanctions are intended to “signal disapproval of the target regime's behaviour, and also to signal the possibility of subsequent punitive measures should that behaviour not change” (Krain 2014, p. 27).
Theory.of.change: If diplomatic sanctions impose reputational costs on potential perpetrators and/or increase their expectation that external actors will impose other costs in the future in response to atrocities, they would reduce the likelihood of mass atrocities. In addition, if diplomatic sanctions damage an abusive leader’s domestic standing, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities by helping facilitate a political transition.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (4) facilitating a political transition.
Name: Tool targets leader family members
Description: The tool targets the leader’s family members.
Inverse.factor: Tool does not target leader family members
Inverse.factor.description: The tool does not target the leader’s family members.
Description.Final_research: The tool targets the leader’s family members.

Short.description: Aid provided by a foreign state to a rebel group
Description_tool: Support to non-state armed groups is assistance--including “the provision of weapons, funds, logistics, military training and access to intelligence and sanctuaries" (Karlen 2017, p. 16)--provided by a foreign state to a non-state armed group (often referred to as a rebel group). This review does not include analyses of direct military intervention in support of a non-state armed group.
Theory.of.change: If support to a non-state armed group enables the group to provide physical protection to civilian populations, to increase costs to other armed actors of committing atrocities (e.g., by attacking them in response to atrocities), or to destroy or degrade other groups’ capacities to commit atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. In addition, if support to a non-state armed group enables it to defeat an abusive government and facilitate a political transition, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities, (3) protecting vulnerable civilian populations, and (4) facilitating a political transition.
Name: Consistent implementation
Description: The tool is implemented consistently over time and across parties/perpetrator groups.
Inverse.factor.description: The tool is implemented inconsistently over time and across parties/perpetrator groups.
Description.Final_research: The tool is implemented consistently over time and across parties/perpetrator groups.

If prosecutions help remove individual perpetrators from positions of power or influence, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities by facilitating a transition to a less atrocity-prone political leadership.
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Name: Implementer has strong leverage
Description: The tool implementer (1) has a significant degree of relative power in the international system, (2) is a member of the “Permanent Five" (P5) countries on the UN Security Council, or (3) has significant leverage over the conflict parties.
Inverse.factor.description: The tool implementer (1) has a low degree of relative power in the international system, (2) is not a member of the “Permanent Five” (P5) countries on the UN Security Council, or (3) has weak leverage over the conflict parties
Description.Final_research: The tool implementer (1) has a significant degree of relative power in the international system, (2) is a member of the “Permanent Five" (P5) countries on the UN Security Council, or (3) has significant leverage over the conflict parties.

Description.Final_research: Atrocities, human rights abuses, or one-sided violence are being perpetrated by the government and non-state armed groups.

Short.description: A non-legal conflict management process facilitated by an external actor
Description_tool: Mediation is “a process of conflict management where disputants seek the assistance of, or accept an offer of help from, an individual, group, state or organization to settle their conflict or resolve their differences without resorting to physical force or invoking the authority of law” (Bercovitch et al. 1991, p. 8).
Theory.of.change: If mediation helps prevent or end an armed conflict, it would reduce the likelihood of mass atrocities because armed conflict is the strongest risk factor for mass atrocities (Bellamy 2011; Straus 2016).
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Name: Change of mediator
Description: The mediator changes during the course of the mediation.
Inverse.factor.description: The mediator is consistent throughout the course of the mediation.
Description.Final_research: The mediator is consistent throughout the course of the mediation.

Short.description: A non-legal conflict management process facilitated by an external actor
Description_tool: Mediation is “a process of conflict management where disputants seek the assistance of, or accept an offer of help from, an individual, group, state or organization to settle their conflict or resolve their differences without resorting to physical force or invoking the authority of law” (Bercovitch et al. 1991, p. 8).
Theory.of.change: If mediation helps prevent or end an armed conflict, it would reduce the likelihood of mass atrocities because armed conflict is the strongest risk factor for mass atrocities (Bellamy 2011; Straus 2016).
Strategies.the.tool.can.support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Name: Conflict parties share organizational membership
Description: The conflict parties are members of the same regional or international organization.
Inverse.factor: Conflict parties do not share organizational membership
Inverse.factor.description: The conflict parties are not members of the same regional or international organization.
Description.Final_research: The conflict parties are members of the same regional or international organization.

Short.description: A non-legal conflict management process facilitated by an external actor
Description_tool: Mediation is “a process of conflict management where disputants seek the assistance of, or accept an offer of help from, an individual, group, state or organization to settle their conflict or resolve their differences without resorting to physical force or invoking the authority of law” (Bercovitch et al. 1991, p. 8).
